title: How to Boil Eggs in an Instant Pot

steps.headline: Pour 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water into your instant pot and put in the steam rack.
steps.description: Use the handles on the steam rack to lower it into the instant pot. The rack comes with the instant pot so you don’t need any extra accessories! Hard-boiled eggs are a great snack to keep in the fridge to eat on their own, or you can make them into deviled eggs.

steps.headline: Place 1-12 eggs on the steam rack and set the pressure to sealing.
steps.description: Gently put the number of eggs you want to prepare on the rack so that they don’t crack. Put the lid on securely and adjust the pressure setting. Depending what size your instant pot is, you may be able to fit more or less eggs.

steps.headline: Set the cook time to 5 minutes and set to high pressure on manual.
steps.description: 5 minutes on high pressure is the perfect amount of time to hard-boil normal sized eggs. For larger eggs add 1-2 minutes to the cook time. It will take about 5 minutes to build up pressure before the cook timer starts counting down.

steps.headline: Fill a bowl with 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water and put in 6-12 ice cubes.
steps.description: Prepare an ice bath while the eggs are cooking. Make sure the bowl is big enough to fit all of the eggs you are cooking. Leave room between the water and the rim of the bowl to avoid overflowing! An ice bath with stop the eggs from overcooking after you remove them from the instant pot.

steps.headline: Let the pressure release naturally for 5 minutes then set it to venting.
steps.description: Use the venting setting after 5 minutes to release the remaining steam. Hold a towel over the valve to avoid getting steam all over the place. Rotate the venting knob from the sealing to the venting position right away when the cook time runs out to begin the natural venting of the instant pot pressure.

steps.headline: Use a spoon to move the eggs from the instant pot to the ice bath.
steps.description: Transfer the eggs using a large kitchen spoon. Leave them to rest in the ice bath for 5 minutes. Don’t pick up the eggs with your fingers or you will burn yourself! You can also run the eggs under cold water for 5 minutes if you don’t have any ice. Hard boiled eggs will stay fresh in the fridge for 1 week.

steps.headline: Fill your instant pot with 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water and lower the steam rack in.
steps.description: Put the steam rack that came with your instant pot in on top of the water after you fill the pot. Use the handles to lower the rack in. Enjoy soft-boiled eggs on their own, or cut them in half and add them to a bowl of noodle soup like ramen!

steps.headline: Put 1-12 eggs in the basket or on top of the steam rack.
steps.description: You will be able to fit up to 12 eggs in your instant pot, depending on what size you have. Place as many eggs as you can on top of the wire rack. The number of eggs you will be able to fit depends on the size of your instant pot.

steps.headline: Set the pressure to high on manual and the cook time to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Add 1 minute to the cook time for very large eggs. Don’t cook the eggs any longer than 4 minutes or you will end up with hard-boiled eggs! The cook timer won’t start counting down until the instant pot builds up pressure, which takes about 5 additional minutes.

steps.headline: Put 6-12 ice cubes in a bowl with 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water.
steps.description: Make sure you leave enough room in the ice bath to place all of the eggs in. Do this while the eggs are cooking so you can transfer them right away when they are finished. The ice bath will cool down the eggs and stop them from cooking more after you remove them from the instant pot, so you end up with the perfect soft-boiled eggs!

steps.headline: Release the pressure naturally for 5 minutes then use venting.
steps.description: Let the pressure lower naturally then release the remaining steam with the venting setting. Place a towel over the steam valve so you don’t spray it everywhere! Turn the venting knob from the sealing to the venting position as soon as the cook time is up to start the natural venting process.

steps.headline: Transfer the eggs from the instant pot into the ice bath with a spoon.
steps.description: Use a large kitchen spoon and gently lift the eggs out of the pot. Place them into the ice bath and let them sit for 5 minutes. Don’t use your hands to pick up the eggs to avoid burning yourself.

text: Hard-Boiling Eggs Pour 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water into your instant pot and put in the steam rack. Use the handles on the steam rack to lower it into the instant pot. The rack comes with the instant pot so you don’t need any extra accessories! Hard-boiled eggs are a great snack to keep in the fridge to eat on their own, or you can make them into deviled eggs. Place 1-12 eggs on the steam rack and set the pressure to sealing. Gently put the number of eggs you want to prepare on the rack so that they don’t crack. Put the lid on securely and adjust the pressure setting. Depending what size your instant pot is, you may be able to fit more or less eggs. Set the cook time to 5 minutes and set to high pressure on manual. 5 minutes on high pressure is the perfect amount of time to hard-boil normal sized eggs. For larger eggs add 1-2 minutes to the cook time. It will take about 5 minutes to build up pressure before the cook timer starts counting down. Fill a bowl with 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water and put in 6-12 ice cubes. Prepare an ice bath while the eggs are cooking. Make sure the bowl is big enough to fit all of the eggs you are cooking. Leave room between the water and the rim of the bowl to avoid overflowing! An ice bath with stop the eggs from overcooking after you remove them from the instant pot. Let the pressure release naturally for 5 minutes then set it to venting. Use the venting setting after 5 minutes to release the remaining steam. Hold a towel over the valve to avoid getting steam all over the place. Rotate the venting knob from the sealing to the venting position right away when the cook time runs out to begin the natural venting of the instant pot pressure. Use a spoon to move the eggs from the instant pot to the ice bath. Transfer the eggs using a large kitchen spoon. Leave them to rest in the ice bath for 5 minutes. Don’t pick up the eggs with your fingers or you will burn yourself! You can also run the eggs under cold water for 5 minutes if you don’t have any ice. Hard boiled eggs will stay fresh in the fridge for 1 week. Making Soft-Boiled Eggs Fill your instant pot with 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water and lower the steam rack in. Put the steam rack that came with your instant pot in on top of the water after you fill the pot. Use the handles to lower the rack in. Enjoy soft-boiled eggs on their own, or cut them in half and add them to a bowl of noodle soup like ramen! Put 1-12 eggs in the basket or on top of the steam rack. You will be able to fit up to 12 eggs in your instant pot, depending on what size you have. Place as many eggs as you can on top of the wire rack. The number of eggs you will be able to fit depends on the size of your instant pot. Set the pressure to high on manual and the cook time to 3 minutes. Add 1 minute to the cook time for very large eggs. Don’t cook the eggs any longer than 4 minutes or you will end up with hard-boiled eggs! The cook timer won’t start counting down until the instant pot builds up pressure, which takes about 5 additional minutes. Put 6-12 ice cubes in a bowl with 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water. Make sure you leave enough room in the ice bath to place all of the eggs in. Do this while the eggs are cooking so you can transfer them right away when they are finished. The ice bath will cool down the eggs and stop them from cooking more after you remove them from the instant pot, so you end up with the perfect soft-boiled eggs! Release the pressure naturally for 5 minutes then use venting. Let the pressure lower naturally then release the remaining steam with the venting setting. Place a towel over the steam valve so you don’t spray it everywhere! Turn the venting knob from the sealing to the venting position as soon as the cook time is up to start the natural venting process. Transfer the eggs from the instant pot into the ice bath with a spoon. Use a large kitchen spoon and gently lift the eggs out of the pot. Place them into the ice bath and let them sit for 5 minutes. Don’t use your hands to pick up the eggs to avoid burning yourself.

Use the handles on the steam rack to lower it into the instant pot.
The rack comes with the instant pot so you don’t need any extra accessories!
Hard-boiled eggs are a great snack to keep in the fridge to eat on their own, or you can make them into deviled eggs.

5 minutes on high pressure is the perfect amount of time to hard-boil normal sized eggs.
For larger eggs add 1-2 minutes to the cook time.
It will take about 5 minutes to build up pressure before the cook timer starts counting down.

You can also run the eggs under cold water for 5 minutes if you don’t have any ice.

Making Soft-Boiled Eggs Fill your instant pot with 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water and lower the steam rack in.
Put the steam rack that came with your instant pot in on top of the water after you fill the pot.
Use the handles to lower the rack in.
Enjoy soft-boiled eggs on their own, or cut them in half and add them to a bowl of noodle soup like ramen!

You will be able to fit up to 12 eggs in your instant pot, depending on what size you have.

The number of eggs you will be able to fit depends on the size of your instant pot.
Set the pressure to high on manual and the cook time to 3 minutes.
Add 1 minute to the cook time for very large eggs.
Don’t cook the eggs any longer than 4 minutes or you will end up with hard-boiled eggs!
The cook timer won’t start counting down until the instant pot builds up pressure, which takes about 5 additional minutes.
Put 6-12 ice cubes in a bowl with 1 cup (236.5 ml) of water.
Make sure you leave enough room in the ice bath to place all of the eggs in.
Do this while the eggs are cooking so you can transfer them right away when they are finished.
The ice bath will cool down the eggs and stop them from cooking more after you remove them from the instant pot, so you end up with the perfect soft-boiled eggs!
Release the pressure naturally for 5 minutes then use venting.
Let the pressure lower naturally then release the remaining steam with the venting setting.
Place a towel over the steam valve so you don’t spray it everywhere!
Turn the venting knob from the sealing to the venting position as soon as the cook time is up to start the natural venting process.
Transfer the eggs from the instant pot into the ice bath with a spoon.
Use a large kitchen spoon and gently lift the eggs out of the pot.
Place them into the ice bath and let them sit for 5 minutes.
Don’t use your hands to pick up the eggs to avoid burning yourself.
